ygData.subject: Re: genotype vs phenotype
ygData.msgSnippet: I m still new to NEAT, but from my limited understanding, if you prevent certain kinds of (add node) innovations from repeating, then there are certain types

I'm still new to NEAT, but from my limited understanding, if you 
prevent certain kinds of (add node) innovations from repeating, then 
there are certain types of net topologies that cannot evolve.  
Specifically, how might a hidden layer evolve that was larger than 
the input/sensor layer?  Horizontal growth as oposed to vertical?

Now that I think of it, I've only seen vertical growth in jNeat.  
Does NEAT prevent horizontal "bulge" in topologies?  And if so, why?

Thanks,
Karl

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> Chad, 
> 
> I agree with what John said.  In addition, this question actually 
> comes up fairly frequently from people new to NEAT, so it is 
> answered in a question in the NEAT FAQ on the NEAT Users Page at:
> 
> http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html
> 
> Please see the question:
> 
> "Should a record of innovations be kept around forever, or only for 
> the current generation?"
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> > >From: "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...>
> > > >Well NEAT does have such a compatibility function, so I take 
> your
> > > >question to be whether you could somehow grade the probability 
> of
> > > >interspecies mating based on the compatibility of various 
> networks,
> > > >and the answer is yes. It is possible to do anything you want 
> based
> > > >on the compatibility function, and using it as a basis for 
> deciding
> > > >which interspecies matings are tolerable is certainly feasible.
> > >
> > >no. I mean what if two mutations are identical but were inovated
> > >seperatly, so that that they are rated as less compatable. In 
the 
> early
> > >part of a search, the ratio of members in a population may be 
> comparable
> > >to the possible number of node insertion points. So if in the 
> second
> > >generation, the same mutation occured as had occured in the first
> > >generation, it would be described as a different gene. Later, as 
> this
> > >phenomenon happens more than once, measured compatability as 
> returned by
> > >the compatiablity function wouldn't reflect the identical 
> mutations.
> > >Am I making a mountain out of a molehill, or am I missing 
> something
> > >important about the compatibility function?
> > 
> > That really depends on how you handle the assignment of 
innovation 
> ID's.  
> > For example, I remember which connection was split to make a 
> node.  Later 
> > (even hundreds of generations later), if a connection between 
> those two 
> > nodes is again split, the new node will receive the same node ID 
> as the 
> > first time.  So if a particular piece of structure happens to 
> evolve twice, 
> > it is recognized as being the same structure.
> > 
> > Ken's implementation doesn't do that, not between generations 
> anyway.  But 
> > at the same time, Ken's implementation has managed to evolve 
> solutions to 
> > things, so obviously it isn't critical.
> > 
> > My suggestion is this:  If you are aware of the possibility of 
> compatible 
> > structures being seen as incompatible, and that bothers you, and 
> you have 
> > the time, energy, and know-how to make sure that doesn't happen, 
> then by all 
> > means, make sure it doesn't happen!  You'll sleep better at 
> night... ;)  
> > Otherwise, don't worry, NEAT will still work just fine. :)
> > 
> > -- John
